page.title: 07A FEN EDGE FARMHOUSE
page.content: Chalk Farm, as its name suggests, stands on an area of chalk soil, in the north-west of the area. The farm belongs to the Church Commissioners and is leased to the tenant farmer. His family have lived in the area for about two hundred years and have been tenants here for about ninety years. The present tenant was born at Chalk Farm. The farmhouse was built in about 1810 out of local Cambridgeshire 'white bricks' which are made from gault clay. It has a slate roof and sash windows. There are several large barns, one of which contains a wall made out of 'clunch', the name given to hard white chalk blocks which are found locally.
